plant.common_name: Kalanchoe / Mother of Millions / Widow's Thrill / Flaming Katy
plant.description:
Brief Description
• Appearance: Kalanchoe plants are herbaceous succulents that can be non-hardy annuals or perennials1. They are characterized by fleshy, opposite leaves that have serrate (saw-toothed) or crenate (scalloped) margins1. They are often winter-flowering, producing bright blooms in colors such as red, orange, or pink arranged in umbels (clusters)1. As the plant ages, the stems often become woody and untidy1.
• Common Locations: They are commonly found as houseplants or garden ornamentals12. Other common names include Cathedral bells

toxins.name: Bufadienolide cardiac glycosides
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Highest Concentration: The toxins are found in all parts of the plant, but the flowers contain the highest concentration of bufadienolides1.
    ◦ Potency: The plant is considered to have high severity toxicity1. While often associated with gastrointestinal signs like vomiting and diarrhea, large ingestions can lead to severe cardiac signs (abnormal heart rate/rhythm), tremors, seizures, and collapse1.... Even a small amount can make a cat ill

symptoms.name: Vomiting, Diarrhea, Drooling (Hypersalivation), Abdominal Pain
symptoms.onset: Within the first 2 hours after exposure.
symptoms.notes: These are the most frequent symptoms. Persistent vomiting can lead to dehydration.Cardiac Abnormalities

symptoms.name: Abnormal Heart Rhythm (Arrhythmias), Bradycardia (Slow Heart Rate), or Tachycardia (Fast Heart Rate)
symptoms.onset: Within the first 2 hours; signs can persist for 4–5 days.
symptoms.notes: The cardiac glycosides inhibit the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia) and potentially fatal heart block or collapse. The flowers contain the highest concentration of toxins.Neurological Dysfunction

symptoms.name: Weakness, Depression, Tremors, Ataxia (Loss of Coordination), Seizures (Rare)
symptoms.notes: Neurological signs like paralysis and tremors indicate significant toxicity. Weakness is a common early sign alongside gastrointestinal upset.Respiratory Distress

symptoms.name: Rapid Breathing (Tachypnea), Difficulty Breathing
symptoms.notes: Rapid breathing often accompanies cardiac and neurological distress.Electrolyte Imbalance

symptoms.name: Hyperkalemia (High Potassium levels)
symptoms.notes: This condition results from the inhibition of the sodium-potassium pump and requires careful monitoring and treatment (e.g., insulin/dextrose or sodium bicarbonate) to prevent cardiac arrest.

treatments.name: Gastrointestinal Decontamination (Emesis and Activated Charcoal)
treatments.description: If the cat is asymptomatic (showing no symptoms yet), the veterinarian will induce vomiting (emesis) to remove plant material from the stomach. This is followed by the administration of activated charcoal with a cathartic to bind toxins.
treatments.notes: Because cardiac glycosides undergo "enterohepatic recirculation" (the body recycles the toxin), veterinarians recommend repeating the dose of activated charcoal (without a cathartic) every 6–8 hours for a total of 3 doses. Do not attempt to induce vomiting at home unless explicitly directed by a professional, as it can be dangerous if the cat is already showing neurological or cardiac signs.

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy
treatments.description: The administration of fluids directly into the vein to maintain blood pressure and hydration.
treatments.notes: This is essential for providing "hemodynamic support" (keeping blood flow stable) and correcting hydration issues caused by the severe vomiting and diarrhea often associated with Kalanchoe ingestion.

treatments.name: Administration of Antidote (Digoxin Immune Fab)
treatments.description: The veterinarian administers Digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Fab), which are antibodies designed to bind to and neutralize the toxins.
treatments.notes: Because the toxins in Kalanchoe are structurally similar to the heart drug digoxin, this specific antidote works well for Kalanchoe poisoning. It is typically reserved for severe cases but is highly effective.

treatments.name: Cardiac Symptom Management (Antiarrhythmics and Atropine)
treatments.description: Specific medications are used to counteract irregular heartbeats. Atropine or glycopyrrolate is used to treat bradycardia (dangerously slow heart rate), while antiarrhythmics like lidocaine are used to stabilize irregular rhythms.
treatments.notes: Kalanchoe toxins inhibit the sodium-potassium pump in heart cells, leading to slower but more forceful contractions. Continuous heart rate monitoring is required for 4–5 days in severe cases.

treatments.name: Electrolyte Management (Hyperkalemia Treatment)
treatments.description: Treatment to lower dangerous potassium levels in the blood, often using sodium bicarbonate or a combination of dextrose and insulin.
treatments.notes: Severe hyperkalemia (high potassium) is a life-threatening complication of cardiac glycoside poisoning. Levels above 7.5–9 mEq/L require immediate aggressive treatment to prevent cardiac arrest.
